subject: Re: [junit] How to test exceptions in java with junit
msgSnippet: ... *snip* ... I ve also taken to coding up a pass() method and I use that in the formerly empty catch block. I think it makes a good complement to the fail()
messageBody:
On 2/24/06, jason r tibbetts <tibbettj@...> wrote:
> Mark Levison wrote:
*snip*

> I like to take the catch block one step further and call
> assertTrue(true) (as has been discussed on this list), or, better yet,
> call something like pass(), which I've defined in a base TestCase to do
> just that. It makes a nice juxtaposition with the fail(), and it keeps
> style checkers from bitching about empty catch clauses.

I've also taken to coding up a pass() method and I use that in the
formerly empty catch block. I think it makes a good complement to the
fail() method as well.

private void pass() {}

That works for me. I slip it at the bottom of the test file. We don't
have a formal wrapper for TestCase around here, so that's the best I
can do.

Simon


--
